However, this process can be fraught with frustration and anxiety for both the child and the parent. One of the most widely accepted methods for teaching a child to ride a bike is the "balance and glide" approach, which involves holding the saddle or providing support while the child learns to balance and glide along a flat surface. This method is often touted as a gentle and non-intimidating way to introduce children to the concept of balancing and steering. However, this approach can also be seen as overly cautious and restrictive, as it fails to challenge the child to take risks and push themselves beyond their comfort zone.
